column3: str
Hm? You've something to ask about the guild, is that it?
What will you ask?
What do you do here?
What is a gladiator?
Nothing.
Well, I don't just stand around gawping, if that's what you're asking. I am Mylla, guildmaster here.
I instruct these would-be warriors on the finer points of swordsmanship. If you like, I could teach you a thing or two as well, though I can't promise to be gentle.
You'll be bruised and bloody by the time we're finished, but I guarantee you'll be stronger for it. Observe our training and see for yourself.
Gladiators aspire to become masters of the sword, the most ubiquitous weapon in all of Eorzea.
The sword is a deceptively simple weapon, which is why many take it up to achieve their goals. Wealth, power, love─all seem within reach when duly armed.
A gladiator, however, understands that to live by the sword is not a decision to be taken lightly. To walk upon the bloodsands is to court death, and we must ever be prepared to enter Thal's realm.
But when you stand triumphant in the Coliseum and hear the crowd chanting your name, you feel...immortal.

Of course, victory goes only to those willing to work for it. A gladiator must rigorously train not only to deliver fierce attacks, but also to weather them. Indeed, learning the shield is just as important as learning the sword.

These defensive skills are especially important when fighting alongside allies. In battle, a gladiator is often relied upon to draw the enemy's attention while his weaker allies seize the opportunity to attack.
It is for this reason that gladiators are often considered indispensable in battle, for none are more skilled in the arts of war than we.
Well, if it isn't <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>! What wind blows you here?
It's not every day a famous free paladin darkens our door. To what do we owe the pleasure, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>?

You are yet welcome here, <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>. Marshal Tarupin made it clear that you were innocent of all charges─not that we needed to be told the truth! No student of mine would dare sully <If(PlayerParameter(4))>her<Else/>his</If> blade with royal blood.
What will you ask?
How fare you of late?
What is a gladiator?
Nothing.
Your concern for my well-being is touching, albeit unwarranted.
I am fine, the guild is fine, Aldis is─ Oh, who gives a damn how Aldis is?
More importantly, any time you waste worrying about the affairs of others would be better spent further honing your skills.
The life of a gladiator is never easy, but I cannot complain. Certain members of the guild have achieved greater recognition in recent days, which has led to a surge of applicants.

They are eager to learn, I will grant them that. Yet they struggle to grasp the basics still. For example, the other day I was explaining the concept of eliciting an opponent's enmity. Surely you recall the lesson? It involved shouting at marauders.
One recruit took forever and a day to understand that his words were not enough, and that he needed to motion to himself to achieve the full effect. Even now, I cannot fathom why he struggled so...

Who are you, and what did you do with <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>? Because I know <If(PlayerParameter(4))>she<Else/>he</If> wouldn't be so daft as to─ Oh, the hells with it.
Gladiators aspire to become masters of the sword, the most ubiquitous weapon in all of Eorzea.
The sword is a deceptively simple weapon, which is why many take it up to achieve their goals. Wealth, power, love─all seem within reach when duly armed.
A gladiator, however, understands that to live by the sword is not a decision to be taken lightly. To walk upon the bloodsands is to court death, and we must ever be prepared to enter Thal's realm.
But when you stand triumphant in the Coliseum and hear the crowd chanting your name, you feel...immortal.

Of course, victory goes only to those willing to work for it. A gladiator must rigorously train not only to deliver fierce attacks, but also to weather them. Indeed, learning the shield is just as important as learning the sword.

These defensive skills are especially important when fighting alongside allies. In battle, a gladiator is often relied upon to draw the enemy's attention while his weaker allies seize the opportunity to attack.

...Just to be clear─You <Emphasis>are</Emphasis> <Split(<Highlight>ObjectParameter(1)</Highlight>, ,1)/>, and not <If(PlayerParameter(4))>her<Else/>his</If> twin <If(PlayerParameter(4))>sister<Else/>brother</If>, right?
Not in use.
